channel.title: My Garage Project
channel.description:
Lately I've been hard at work on a garage to put all my cars, tractor, lawn mowers and various other junk in. It is 32' x 56', with 14' tall ceilings so I can put a car lift in there to work on cars easier with. For now it will just have a gravel floor and no electricity, I plan on wiring it and having gravel poured next year, if I have the money. Here is a picture of my latest progress, where we have done everything we can do without ladders and scaffolding that I went and picked up today. I've done this all myself with help from my dad and uncle alternativly. I drew up my own plans and such that I may post later if anyones interested, anyway, here it is:
[URL=http://img188.imageshack.us/img188/9485/img20100831173404.jpg][IMG]http://img188.imageshack.us/img188/9485/img20100831173404.th.jpg[/img][/URL]
(taken with my phone, which for some reason when you look close makes it look like a painting, odd...)

item.title: My Garage Project
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

A quick update, all of the poles are built all the way up now, another round of 2x4s around it are up (4 down, 2 more to go), and I’ve got my walk-in door post sank in concrete and it’s all framed up. Also the trusses were just delivered today. Tomorrow I would have it the rest of the way ready to put the trusses on except weather.com and the news says we are going to have thunder-storms, so it might push me back to next week. I’ll try to snap some pictures if I get a chance. I’m all sunburned and literally have a bright red neck right now.

Read full topic

item.title: My Garage Project
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

Wait you have to have a qualified electrician do this stuff. That sounds like alot of bullshit I don’t even think you need a permit. Ive been doing electrical work for money and the only thing I needed was to have an electrical inspector approve it. I don’t have any permits…

I don’t know about it being a legal requirement; I’m pointing out that insurance companies will fuck with you if a DIY job goes wrong – they’ll use lack of professional installation as justification for not paying.

Read full topic

item.title: My Garage Project
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Lothy:

I just remember when my stepfather was helping build the new shooting ranges at the pistol club, they had to have someone who was a qualified electrician sign off on the job so that it could be insured.

It’s the same here, the best solution is to make friends with an electrician

Read full topic

item.title: My Garage Project
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:30, topic:358106”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=454617.msg3331667#msg3331667 date=1283533826]

I believe I can wire it to code and not need an electrician at all. I’m not hiring a damn electrician for something I can do myself.

It’s not about whether you can do something or not most of the time. I just remember when my stepfather was helping build the new shooting ranges at the pistol club, they had to have someone who was a qualified electrician sign off on the job so that it could be insured.

In Canada anyways you are allowed to wire most things yourself and not have to tell anyone about it. There’s been many cases where the original “electrician” who wired the house did a terrible job to save money so we’ve had to bring it up to code ourselves.
[/quote]
What happens in the event that the house burns down because a lightswitch is wired up incorrectly or something though? Does the insurance company make the payout still, or is their obligation to do so non-existent if they can prove that the fire was a result of negligence on the owner’s part by not having something done professionally?[/quote]If it is deemed as a problem in the house wiring itself, and as long as it wasn’t the owner who wired it, they still payout.

Read full topic

item.title: My Garage Project
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:29, topic:358106”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=454617.msg3331502#msg3331502 date=1283523821]

I believe I can wire it to code and not need an electrician at all. I’m not hiring a damn electrician for something I can do myself.

It’s not about whether you can do something or not most of the time. I just remember when my stepfather was helping build the new shooting ranges at the pistol club, they had to have someone who was a qualified electrician sign off on the job so that it could be insured.
[/quote]
In Canada anyways you are allowed to wire most things yourself and not have to tell anyone about it. There’s been many cases where the original “electrician” who wired the house did a terrible job to save money so we’ve had to bring it up to code ourselves.[/quote]
What happens in the event that the house burns down because a lightswitch is wired up incorrectly or something though? Does the insurance company make the payout still, or is their obligation to do so non-existent if they can prove that the fire was a result of negligence on the owner’s part by not having something done professionally?

Read full topic

item.title: My Garage Project
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Electricity Permit? That’s insane, for a good year or so we had two extension cords running to ours, with a plastic bag taped around the join so the water couldn’t get in… except when it did and tripped the RCD occasionally.

Maybe I shouldn’t admit that on the internets actually

Read full topic
